awd_titl_txt: Berkeley Conference in Inner Model Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The Berkeley Conference on Inner Model Theory will be held July 8-19, 2019 at the Department of Mathematics, University of California, Berkeley. It will be devoted to significant recent progress in inner model theory. The new work includes advances in iteration tree combinatorics, leading to a general comparison theorem for the iteration strategies of mice having no long extenders, and from there to a new theory of the hereditarily ordinal definable sets in models of the Axiom of Determinacy. The Berkeley conference will gather experts in inner model theory from around the world, as well as students and postdocs with a serious interest in the field, in order to communicate and pursue the new ideas.


Large cardinal hypotheses play a central role in the set-theoretic foundations of mathematics. The inner model program attempts to
associate to each large cardinal hypothesis a canonical minimal universe of sets in which that hypothesis is true. Some of our deepest understanding of large cardinal hypotheses come from this program. The core model induction method is our most powerful method for constructing such canonical inner models, and this conference will be devoted to recent work that strengthens the method in important ways. The website for the conference is  https://ivv5hpp.uni-muenster.de/u/rds/berkeley_meeting_2019.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
The Berkeley Conference in Inner Model Theory was held

July 8-19, 2019, at UC Berkeley. It was attended by 5 students,

5 postdocs, and 11 senior researchers. The conference consisted of formal

lectures, tutorials, problem sessions, and informal discussions

related to recent advances in the theory of canonical inner models for large

cardinal hypotheses. This is a part of pure set theory devoted

to developing and studying concrete, minimal models

of the large cardinal hypotheses upon which much of set theory depends.

There has been significant progress on this front in recent years. This

conference was one in a series of conferences devoted to disseminating it.

 

In particular, there was a lecture series on the comparison

of iteration strategies, and its applications to

the analysis of ordinal definability and the pattern of

Suslin cardinals in models of the Axiom of Determinacy.

There were also lecture series 

on the consistency strength of generic absoluteness for the theory

of the Universally Baire sets, and on the combinatorics of meta-iteration trees.

There were talks on the Ultrapower Axiom and on the consistency

strength of mutual stationarity principles. The informal discussions

led to progress on some of the open problems identified in the talks.

The conference website provides a more detailed account of the proceedings.

 

This award supported travel by 3 students and 2 postdocs to attend

the conference.


Last Modified: 09/27/2021
Modified by: John R Steel
